briefdescription.para: Enum defining available types of position representations.
Enum defining available types of position representations.
Spherical coordinate indices.

detaileddescription.para: Spherical coordinate indices, for position and velocity components. With r the radius, theta the azimuthal angle, phi the elevational angle. Vr, Vtheta, Vphi are the velocities along the corresponding base vectors of r, theta, phi.

briefdescription.para: Cylindrical coordinate indices.

detaileddescription.para: Cylindrical coordinate vector indices, for position and velocity components.

briefdescription.para: Cartesian coordinate indices.

detaileddescription.para: Cartesian coordinate vector indices, for position and velocity components.

briefdescription.para: Calculate the ellipticity of an ellipsoid.

detaileddescription.para:
Calculates the ellipticity of an ellipsoid from its flattening. From Montenbruck & Gill (2000). Note: The ellipticity is not to be confused with the eccentricity.
flattening
Flattening of the ellipsoid.
Ellipticity of the ellipsoid.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d cartesianPosition, const double equatorialRadius, const double ellipticity, const double tolerance)
memberdef.name: calculateGeodeticCoordinatesAuxiliaryQuantities

briefdescription.para: Calculate auxiliary quantities for geodetic coordinate conversions.

detaileddescription.para:
Calculates auxiliary quantities for geodetic coordinate conversions. (Montenbruck & Gill, 2010, Fig 5.12). The auxiliary quantities are determined by creating a line through the cartesianPosition, perpendicular to the surface and finding its intercept with the z-axis. The distance between the body surface and the z-axis intercept is the first auxiliary quantity, the offset in z-direction of the intersect point from the origin is the second auxiliary variable.
cartesianPosition
Cartesian position in body-fixed frame where altitude is to be determined.
equatorialRadius
Equatorial radius of oblate spheroid.
ellipticity
Ellipticity of oblate spheroid.
tolerance
Convergence criterion for iterative algorithm that is employed. Represents the required change of position (in m) between two iterations.
Auxiliary parameters for geodetic coordinate conversions.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d geodeticCoordinates, const double equatorialRadius, const double flattening)
memberdef.name: convertGeodeticToCartesianCoordinates

briefdescription.para: Calculate the Cartesian position from geodetic coordinates.

detaileddescription.para:
Calculates the Cartesian position from geodetic coordinates (altitude, geodetic latitude, longitude).
geodeticCoordinates
Geodetic coordinates w.r.t. given body.
equatorialRadius
Equatorial radius of oblate spheroid.
flattening
Flattening of oblate spheroid.
Cartesian position in body-fixed frame.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d cartesianPosition, const double zInterceptOffset, const double interceptToSurfaceDistance)
memberdef.name: calculateAltitudeOverOblateSpheroid

briefdescription.para: Calculate the altitude over an oblate spheroid of a position vector from auxiliary variables.

detaileddescription.para:
Calculates the altitude over an oblate spheroid of a position vector. This function gets the auxiliary variables(see calculateGeodeticCoordinatesAuxiliaryQuantities) as input. These values are determined by drawing the line L from cartesianPosition perpendicular to the ellipsoid and calculating the intercept with the z-axis.
cartesianPosition
Cartesian position in body-fixed frame where altitude is to be determined.
zInterceptOffset
Offset of intercept of line L with z-axis from origin in z-direction.
interceptToSurfaceDistance
Distance from intercept of line L with z-axis to body surface
Altitude above specified oblate spheroid at requested point.
calculateGeodeticCoordinatesAuxiliaryQuantities

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d cartesianPosition, const double equatorialRadius, const double flattening, const double tolerance)
memberdef.name: calculateAltitudeOverOblateSpheroid

briefdescription.para: Calculate the altitude over an oblate spheroid of a position vector.

detaileddescription.para:
Calculates the altitude over an oblate spheroid of a position vector. The algorithm that is used is iterative, so that it requires a tolerance (in m) for the difference of associated geodetic position between two iterations.
cartesianPosition
Cartesian position in body-fixed frame where altitude is to be determined.
equatorialRadius
Equatorial radius of oblate spheroid.
flattening
Flattening of oblate spheroid.
tolerance
Convergence criterion for iterative algorithm that is employed. Represents the required change of position (in m) between two iterations.
Altitude above specified oblate spheroid at requested point.

briefdescription.para: Calculate the geodetic latitude from Cartesian position and offset of z-intercept.

detaileddescription.para:
Calculates the geodetic latitude from Cartesian position and offset of z-intercept. This intercept is determined by drawing the line from cartesianPosition perpendicular to the ellipsoid and calculating the offset from the origin where it intercepts the z-axis.
cartesianPosition
Cartesian position in body-fixed frame where geodetic latitude is to be determined.
zInterceptOffset
Offset from origin of intersection with z-axis of line perpendicular to surface from cartesianPosition.
Geodetic latitude above specified oblate spheroid at requested point.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d cartesianPosition, const double equatorialRadius, const double flattening, const double tolerance)
memberdef.name: calculateGeodeticLatitude

briefdescription.para: Calculate the geodetic latitude of a position vector.

detaileddescription.para:
Calculates the geodetic latitude of a position vector on an oblate spheroid. The algorithm that is used is iterative, so that it requires a tolerance (in m) for the difference of associated geodetic position between two iterations.
cartesianPosition
Cartesian position in body-fixed frame where geodetic latitude is to be determined.
equatorialRadius
Equatorial radius of oblate spheroid.
flattening
Flattening of oblate spheroid.
tolerance
Convergence criterion for iterative algorithm that is employed. Represents the required change of position (in m) between two iterations.
Geodetic latitude above specified oblate spheroid at requested point.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d cartesianCoordinates, const double equatorialRadius, const double flattening, const double tolerance)
memberdef.name: convertCartesianToGeodeticCoordinates

briefdescription.para: Calculate geodetic coordinates (altitude, geodetic latitude, longitude) of a position vector.

detaileddescription.para: Calculate geodetic coordinates ( altitude, geodetic latitude, longitude ) of a position vector.

Calculates the geodetic coordinates (altitude, geodetic latitude, longitude) of a position vector. The algorithm that is used is iterative, so that it requires a tolerance (in m) for the difference of associated geodetic position between two iterations.
cartesianCoordinates
Cartesian position in body-fixed frame where geodetic coordinates are to be determined.
equatorialRadius
Equatorial radius of oblate spheroid.
flattening
Flattening of oblate spheroid.
tolerance
Convergence criterion for iterative algorithm that is employed. Represents the required change of position (in m) between two iterations.
Geodetic coordinates at requested point.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Eigen::Vector3d &originalElements, const PositionElementTypes originalElementTypes, const PositionElementTypes convertedElementTypes, const std::shared_ptr< basic_astrodynamics::BodyShapeModel > shapeModel=nullptr, const double tolerance=1.0E-4)
memberdef.name: convertPositionElements

briefdescription.para: Function to convert a position from one representation to another.

detaileddescription.para:
Function to convert a position from one representation to another
originalElements
Position in element type given by originalElementTypes
originalElementTypes
Element type used for input.
convertedElementTypes
Element type to which originalElements is to be converted.
shapeModel
Shape model associated with position (only required for specific element types, e.g. geodetic) default nullptr.
tolerance
Tolerance used for conversion (only required for specific element types, e.g. geodetic), default 0.1 mm.
Position in requested element type.

briefdescription.para: Convert spherical (radius, zenith, azimuth) to Cartesian (x,y,z) coordinates.

detaileddescription.para:
Converts spherical to cartesian coordinates. Schematic representation can be found on, e.g., http://mathworld.wolfram.com/SphericalCoordinates.html. The transformation equations are the following, with $ r $ the radius, $ \theta $ the azimuth angle and $ \phi $ the zenith angle: \begin{eqnarray*} x &=& r\cos\theta\sin\phi \\ y &=& r\sin\theta\sin\phi \\ z &=& r\cos\phi \\ \end{eqnarray*}
sphericalCoordinates
Vector containing radius, zenith and azimuth (in that order).
Vector containing Cartesian coordinates, as calculated from sphericalCoordinates.

briefdescription.para: Convert Cartesian (x,y,z) to spherical (radius, zenith, azimuth) coordinates.

detaileddescription.para:
Converts Cartesian to spherical coordinates. Schematic representation can be found on, e.g., http://mathworld.wolfram.com/SphericalCoordinates.html. The transformation equations are the following, with $ r $ the radius, $ \theta $ the azimuth angle and $ \phi $ the zenith angle: \begin{eqnarray*} r &=& \sqrt{ x^{ 2 } + y^{ 2 } + z^{ 2 } } \\ \theta &=& \arctan\frac{ y }{ x } \\ \phi &=& \arccos\frac{ z }{ r } \\ \end{eqnarray*}
cartesianCoordinates
Vector containing Cartesian coordinates.
Vector containing sphericalCoordinates radius, zenith and azimuth (in that order), as calculated from sphericalCoordinates.

memberdef.argsstring: (const double radius, const double azimuthAngle, const double z)
memberdef.name: convertCylindricalToCartesian

briefdescription.para: Convert cylindrical to Cartesian coordinates.

detaileddescription.para:
Converts cylindrical to Cartesian coordinates. Schematic representation can be found on, e.g., http://mathworld.wolfram.com/CylindricalCoordinates.html. The transformation equations are the following, with $ r $ the radius and $ \theta $ the azimuth angle [rad]: \begin{eqnarray*} x &=& r\cos \theta \\ y &=& r\sin \theta \\ z &=& z \\ \end{eqnarray*}
radius
Cylindrical radial coordinate r.
azimuthAngle
Cylindrical azimuthal coordinate $ \theta $ [rad].
z
Cylindrical height coordinate z.
Vector of Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].

briefdescription.para: Convert cylindrical to cartesian coordinates.

detaileddescription.para:
Converts cylindrical to cartesian coordinates. Schematic representation can be found on, e.g., http://mathworld.wolfram.com/CylindricalCoordinates.html. The transformation equations are the following, with $ r $ the radius and $ \theta $ the azimuth angle [rad]: \begin{eqnarray*} x &=& r\cos \theta \\ y &=& r\sin \theta \\ z &=& z \\ \end{eqnarray*}
cylindricalCoordinates
Vector of cylindrical coordinates [r,theta,z].
Vector of Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].

briefdescription.para: Convert cylindrical to Cartesian state.

detaileddescription.para:
Converts cylindrical to Cartesian state. Schematic representation can be found on, e.g., http://mathworld.wolfram.com/CylindricalCoordinates.html and http://staffweb.cms.gre.ac.uk/~ct02/research/thesis/node26.html. The transformation equations are the following, with $ r $ the radius and $ \theta $ the azimuth angle [rad]: \begin{eqnarray*} x &=& r\cos \theta \\ y &=& r\sin \theta \\ z &=& z \\ \dot{x} &=& V_r\cos{\theta} - V_{\theta}\sin{theta} \\ \dot{y} &=& V_r\sin{\theta} + V_{\theta}\cos{theta} \\ \dot{z} &=& V_z \end{eqnarray*}
cylindricalState
Vector of cylindrical state [r,theta,z,Vr,Vtheta,Vz], where Vtheta = r*thetadot.
Vector of Cartesian state [x,y,z,xdot,ydot,zdot].

briefdescription.para: Convert Cartesian to cylindrical coordinates.

detaileddescription.para:
Converts Cartesian to cylindrical coordinates. Schematic representation can be found on, e.g., http://mathworld.wolfram.com/CylindricalCoordinates.html. The transformation equations are the following, with $ r $ the radius and $ \theta $ the azimuth angle [rad] [0,2 $ \pi $]: \begin{eqnarray*} r &=& \sqrt{x^2+y^2} \\ \theta &=& \arctan{\frac{y}{x}} \\ z &=& z \end{eqnarray*}
cartesianCoordinates
Vector of Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
Vector of cylindrical coordinates [r,theta,z].

briefdescription.para: Convert Cartesian to cylindrical state.

detaileddescription.para:
Converts Cartesian to cylindrical state. Schematic representation can be found on, e.g., http://mathworld.wolfram.com/CylindricalCoordinates.html and http://staffweb.cms.gre.ac.uk/~ct02/research/thesis/node26.html. The transformation equations are the following, with $ r $ the radius, $ \theta $ the azimuth angle [rad] [0,2 $\pi$] and $ V_r $, $ V_{\theta} $ and $ V_z $ the linear cylindrical velocities: \begin{eqnarray*} r &=& \sqrt{x^2+y^2} \\ \theta &=& \arctan{\frac{y}{x}} \\ z &=& z \\ V_r = \dot{r} &=& \frac{x\dot{x}+y\dot{y}}{\sqrt{x^2+y^2}} \\ V_{\theta} = r\dot{\theta} &=& \frac{x\dot{y}-y\dot{x}}{\sqrt{x^2+y^2}} \\ V_z = \dot{z} \end{eqnarray*}
cartesianState
Vector of Cartesian state [x,y,z,xdot,ydot,zdot].
Vector of cylindrical state [r,theta,z,Vr,Vtheta,Vz], where Vtheta = r*thetadot.

briefdescription.para: Compute matrix by which to precompute a spherical gradient vector to obtain the Cartesian gradient.

detaileddescription.para:
Compute matrix by which to precompute a spherical gradient vector to obtain the Cartesian gradient
cartesianCoordinates
Vector with Cartesian position at which gradient is computed.
Matrix by which to precompute a spherical gradient vector to obtain the Cartesian gradient

briefdescription.para: Convert spherical to Cartesian gradient.

detaileddescription.para:
This function converts a gradient vector with respect to spherical coordinates to a gradient vector with respect to Cartesian coordinates. The partial derivatives are calculated according to Vallado [2001] as: \begin{eqnarray*} \frac{ \partial U }{ \partial x } & = & \frac{ x }{ \sqrt{ x^2 + y^2 +z^2 } } \frac{ \partial U }{ \partial r } - \frac{ x z }{ ( x^2 + y^2 +z^2 ) \sqrt{ x^2 + y^2 } } \frac{ \partial U }{ \partial \phi } - \frac{ y }{ x^2 + y^2 } \frac{ \partial U }{ \partial \lambda } \\ \frac{ \partial U }{ \partial y } & = & \frac{ y }{ \sqrt{ x^2 + y^2 +z^2 } } \frac{ \partial U }{ \partial r } - \frac{ y z }{ ( x^2 + y^2 +z^2 ) \sqrt{ x^2 + y^2 } } \frac{ \partial U }{ \partial \phi } + \frac{ x }{ x^2 + y^2 } \frac{ \partial U }{ \partial \lambda } \\ \frac{ \partial U }{ \partial z } & = & \frac{ z }{ \sqrt{ x^2 + y^2 +z^2 } } \frac{ \partial U }{ \partial r } + \frac{ \sqrt{ x^2 + y^2 } } { x^2 + y^2 +z^2 } \frac{ \partial U }{ \partial \phi } \end{eqnarray*} in which $ x $, $ y $ and $ z $ are the Cartesian coordinates. $ U $ is an arbitrary scalar. Radius $ r $ is the length of the position vector. Elevation $ \phi $ is the the angle between the position vector and the XY-plane (with the positive direction towards the Z-axis). Azimuth $ \lambda $ is the dihedral angle about the Z-axis between the X-axis and the position vector (with the positive direction being right-handed about the Z-axis).
sphericalGradient
Vector with partial derivatives with respect to spherical coordinates. The order is important! sphericalGradient( 0 ) = partial derivative with respect to radius, sphericalGradient( 1 ) = partial derivative with respect to elevation, sphericalGradient( 2 ) = partial derivative with respect to azimuth.
cartesianCoordinates
Vector with Cartesian coordinates. The order is important! cartesianCoordinates( 0 ) = x coordinate, cartesianCoordinates( 1 ) = y coordinate, cartesianCoordinates( 2 ) = z coordinate.
Vector with partial derivatives with respect to Cartesian coordinates. The order is important! cartesianGradient( 0 ) = partial derivative with respect to x coordinate, cartesianGradient( 1 ) = partial derivative with respect to y coordinate, cartesianGradient( 2 ) = partial derivative with respect to z coordinate.
Function to compute the derivative of the Cartesian gradient w.r.t. the Cartesian position, keeping the spherical gradient constant.

Function to compute the derivative of the Cartesian gradient w.r.t. the Cartesian position, keeping the spherical gradient constant.
sphericalGradient
Value of spherical gradient (derivatives w.r.t. radius, latitude and longitude).
cartesianCoordinates
Cartesian position at whichr result is to be computed.
subMatrices
Subcomputations performed by this function: derivatives of results of getSphericalToCartesianGradientMatrix, w.r.t. x, y and z component of cartesianCoordinates, respectively.
Require derivative of cartesian gradient.
Function to compute the derivative of the Cartesian gradient w.r.t. the Cartesian position, keeping the spherical gradient constant.

Function to compute the derivative of the Cartesian gradient w.r.t. the Cartesian position, keeping the spherical gradient constant.
sphericalGradient
Value of spherical gradient (derivatives w.r.t. radius, latitude and longitude).
cartesianCoordinates
Cartesian position at whichr result is to be computed..
Require derivative of cartesian gradient.

briefdescription.para: Convert spherical to Cartesian state.

detaileddescription.para: Converts a spherical state to a Cartesian state. The transformation matrices are computed according to Torok [2000, pp.10-11].
NOTE: This function is implemented separately from the other conversions due to a different definition of the elevation/zenith angle. This should be consolidated in a future update.

The transformation equations are the following, with $ r $ the radius (positive from origin to the point in orbit, in meters), $ \theta $ the azimuth angle (positive from the x-axis to the y-axis, in radians) and $ \phi $ the elevation angle (positive from the xy-plane to the z-axis, in radians): \begin{eqnarray*} x &=& r * \cos \phi * \cos \theta\\ y &=& r * \cos \phi * \sin \theta\\ z &=& r * \sin \phi\\ CartesianVelocities = T_{cyl2cart}*T_{sph2cyl}*SphericalVelocities \end{eqnarray*} with \begin{eqnarray*} T_{sph2cyl} = [ \cos\phi , 0.0 , -\sin \phi ; 0.0 , 1.0 , 0.0 ; \sin\phi , 0.0 , \cos\phi ]\\ T_{cyl2cart} = [ \cos\theta , -\sin\theta , 0.0 ; \sin\theta , \cos\theta , 0.0 ; 0.0 , 0.0 , 1.0 ]\\ \end{eqnarray*}

sphericalState
Vector containing the spherical coordinates and spherical velocities. The order is important! sphericalState( 0 ) = radius r [m], sphericalState( 1 ) = azimuth theta [rad], sphericalState( 2 ) = elevation phi [rad], sphericalState( 3 ) = radial velocity Vr [m/s], sphericalState( 4 ) = azimuthal velocity Vtheta [m/s], sphericalState( 5 ) = elevational velocity Vphi [m/s].
Vector containing the Cartesian state (both position and velocity, in that order). cartesianState( 0 ) = x [m], cartesianState( 1 ) = y [m], cartesianState( 2 ) = z [m], cartesianState( 3 ) = Vx [m/s], cartesianState( 4 ) = Vy [m/s], cartesianState( 5 ) = Vz [m/s].
Take care: here the elevation is used, not the zenith angle!

briefdescription.para: Convert Cartesian to spherical state.

detaileddescription.para: Converts a Cartesian state to a spherical state. The transformation matrices are computed according to Torok [2000, pp.10-11].
NOTE: This function is implemented separately from the other conversions due to a different definition of the elevation/zenith angle. This should be consolidated in a future update.

The transformation equations are the following, with $ r $ the radius (positive from origin to the point in orbit), $ \theta $ the azimuth angle (positive from the x-axis to the y-axis) and $ \phi $ the elevation angle (positive from the xy-plane to the z-axis): \begin{eqnarray*} r &=& \sqrt{ x^{ 2 } + y^{ 2 } + z^{ 2 } } \\ \phi &=& \arcsin\frac{ z }{ r } \\ \theta &=& \arctan\frac{ y }{ x } \\ SphericalVelocities = T_{cyl2sph}*T_{cart2cyl}*CartesianVelocities \end{eqnarray*} with \begin{eqnarray*} T_{cyl2sph} = [ \cos\phi , 0.0 , \sin \phi ; 0.0 , 1.0 , 0.0 ; -\sin\phi , 0.0 , \cos\phi ]\\ T_{cart2cyl} = [ \cos\theta , \sin\theta , 0.0 ; -\sin\theta , \cos\theta , 0.0 ; 0.0 , 0.0 , 1.0 ]\\ \end{eqnarray*}

cartesianState
Vector containing the Cartesian coordinates and Cartesian velocities. The order is important! cartesianState( 0 ) = x [m], cartesianState( 1 ) = y [m], cartesianState( 2 ) = z [m], cartesianState( 3 ) = Vx [m/s], cartesianState( 4 ) = Vy [m/s], cartesianState( 5 ) = Vz [m/s].
Vector containing the spherical state (both position and velocity, in that order). The order is important! sphericalState( 0 ) = radius r [m], sphericalState( 1 ) = azimuth theta [rad], sphericalState( 2 ) = elevation phi [rad], sphericalState( 3 ) = radial velocity Vr [m/s], sphericalState( 4 ) = azimuthal velocity Vtheta [m/s], sphericalState( 5 ) = elevational velocity Vphi [m/s].
Take care: here the elevation is used, not the zenith!
